content.content: An infection that happens from a central catheter. A central catheter is a tube in a large vein in the neck, chest or groin. [^66] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/sFROH5rvWOY ### Symptoms: - Redness near the tube - Red streaks near the tube - Swelling - Warmth - Yellow or green liquid - Pain or soreness - Fever - Chills [^66] ### Prevention: __Use the Hospital Plan of Care form to advocate and ask questions about your loved one.__ [The Hospital Plan of Care form](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/POC-Blank-April-19.pdf "The Hospital Plan of Care form") [Guide to Medical Care at a Distance](https://patientsafetymovement.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/Guide-to-Medical-Care-at-a-Distance.pdf "Guide to Medical Care at a Distance") __Don’t touch where your IV lines are.__ ![central line](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/1VNQ5iOqsQA8MKWaqOASQG/af200796edf86741528626b907422330/central_line.jpeg) __When a central catheter IV line is inserted, make sure there is:__ - Careful hand washing - Barrier precautions used during line insertion (including hair cover, mask, sterile gloves, sterile gown, eye protection and drape) - Cleaning the skin with chlorhexidine gluconate skin prep - The skin prep needs to be dry before inserting the central line - Avoid using the femoral vein (upper leg near the groin) - Daily review of the need for the central catheter IV and prompt removal of unnecessary catheters.[^80][^81] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/-DNuFp6KDVM All healthcare providers and visitors must wash their hands. The average handwashing rate is 40% for healthcare providers in the hospital.[^58] __Never be afraid to ask your doctor or nurse to please wash their hands!__ Embedded content: https://youtu.be/tZnKlFtAUDw [Infection Prevention and You from APIC](http://www.apic.org/Resource_/TinyMceFileManager/consumers_professionals/APIC_IPandYou_YouAreImportant.pdf) ![handwashing](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3Qs1rsgcAwie0O404EcMW0/6e1c030c5df8f406f93b6163dd1a1eb4/handwashing.jpeg) [Clean Hands Count from the CDC](http://www.cdc.gov/handhygiene/pdfs/patient-factsheet-508.pdf "Clean Hands Count from the CDC") Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l4HpcOpQaoQ 1\. Bring in hand sanitizer for the patient, healthcare providers, and visitors to use. Ask your doctor or nurse to wash their hands __with__ you.[^7] ![hand sanitizer provider](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/2q5V25fwig4Ak4SGgiEio/4c336dc17006aa5df8d94657aac89786/hand_sanitizer_provider.jpeg) 2\. Use disinfectant wipes on all surfaces that you or the patient will come in contact with. Ask the nurse for these.[^61] ![sanitizing wipe](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/smiMs9183uw0MI8MokmSy/ee88d5019c968395e32e34a21128feed/sanitizing_wipe.jpeg) 3\. Put up a sign asking staff to wash their hands on your door and above your bed.[^7] Embedded content: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M8AKTACyiB0 4\. Make sure doctors and nurses wipe the round end of the stethoscope with an alcohol wipe.[^61] 5\. Gloves need to be worn when there is contact with blood or other body fluids, mouth, nose, lungs, urinary and digestive tracts, open skin areas, or items that are soiled with blood or other body fluids. __Healthcare workers need to wash their hands both before and after using gloves. Wearing gloves is never a substitute for hand washing![^7] Gloves can have microscopic tears and holes.__ ![nitrile gloves](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4rg2Fta5E4aeiaigMMIwEK/394f7d31c513fcc1ce76efacff603cc7/nitrile_gloves.jpeg) 6\. Healthcare providers and visitors need to follow Isolation Precautions of wearing gowns, gloves and sometimes masks if the patient's door has an Isolation Precaution sign on it. [Isolation Precaution Information from the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000446.htm) ![isolation stuff](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6VTF4KABnayciesYuYEGMY/5b5f6c8e53d2c9261b6e6c7df9876595/isolation_stuff.svg) 7\. The patient must wash their hands before eating every meal and before going to sleep.[^7] 8\. The patient needs toothbrushing, &/or denture cleaning, & mouth rinsing 2-4 times every day.[^68] 9\. Deep breathing, incentive spirometer & coughing exercises every hour while awake. __The patient should do at least 10 deep breaths every hour using the incentive spirometer while in bed.__[^78] ![incentive spirometer](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/4FE0Ueh8xi8C8aOoM8euUC/28cc668d6148ca40013aeff37a2a740a/incentive_spirometer.jpeg) 10\. When is the soonest the patient can safely get out of bed & walk?[^68] 11\. Cellphones are dirty[^63][^64] - Wipe your cell phone with an alcohol wipe. - Do not take a cell phone into the bathroom. - Do not place the cell phone on the floor, especially the bathroom floor. 12\. Cover your mouth when you cough or sneeze. Use your elbow or arm instead of your hands. 13\. When a nurse is giving IV medications, make sure the nurse cleans the IV port for 15 seconds before and after with an alcohol wipe.[^65] Don’t touch __where your IV lines meet your skin__.[^66] ![iv arm](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/6UwMhxhQjeYysEGk8GgiC8/b22dc225e9d6b286d7ac3995eb4faed9/iv_arm.jpeg) 14\. Tell your nurse and doctor if there is pain, swelling, redness, itching or wetness at an IV line or incision.[^7] Embedded content: https://youtu.be/67vDXQMxUz4 15\. Ask if you or the patient can have their own blood pressure cuff to be used only by them.[^7] ![stethoscope bpc](//images.ctfassets.net/xbvvg00rroa3/3rEpJHB2R2g8uu44yAe8Qc/490f0da52aec12da4fa003b064c00cab/stethoscope_bpc.jpeg) 16\. Remove your slippers worn over socks __before getting back into your bed. This prevents germs from the floor coming into your bed.__[^7] 17\. All visitors need to[^7]: - Wash their hands before entering and leaving the room - Do not visit if they feel ill - Avoid using the patient’s bathroom [Prevention of Infections from Visitors by the National Library of Medicine](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000448.htm) [Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infection Information from the CDC ](https://www.cdc.gov/HAI/bsi/CLABSI-resources.html) [Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infection Information from Medline Plus](https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000474.htm) [Central Venous Catheter Information from the American Thoracic Society ](https://www.thoracic.org/patients/patient-resources/resources/central-venous-catheter.pdf) [^66]: CDC. Central Catheter-associated Bloodstream Infections: Resources for Patients and Healthcare Providers. https://www.cdc.gov/HAI/bsi/CLABSI-resources.html. Reviewed February 7, 2011. Accessed July 4, 2020. [^67]: U.S. National Library of Medicine. Central line infections-hospitals. Medline Plus website. https://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/patientinstructions/000474.htm. Reviewed February 18, 2018. Updated June 2, 2020. Accessed July 4, 2020. [^80]: O'Grady NP, Alexander M, Burns LA, et al. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention website. 2011 Guidelines for the prevention of intravascular catheter-related infections. http://www.cdc.gov/hicpac/BSI/BSI-guidelines-2011.html. Reviewed April 1, 2011. Accessed December 5, 2015. [^81]: Daniels KR and Frei CR. The United States’ progress toward eliminating catheter-related bloodstream infections: incidence, mortality, and hospital length of stay from 1996-2008. American Journal of Infection Control. 2013 February;41(2):118-21.
